poem:
The Steelworks' Future  

Amid the clang  
of steel and  
uncertain sands,  
Scunthorpe stands—  
a giant, poised.  
Whispers of  
options, each sound  
echoes through  
the veins of time.  

National breath  
held as  
hammers wait,  
while Starmer's voice  
reflects the weight—  
steel cold,  
yet undecided.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "UK politics: ‘All options on table’ for Scunthorpe steelworks, says Starmer, amid calls for nationalisation – as it happened 6.21pm BST Early evening summary Keir Starmer has said all options should remain on the table for the future of British Steel’s Scunthorpe plant – amid reports that the government is “seriously considering” nationalising the plant. (See 3.34pm.) Rachel Reeves has declined to back calls for the UK government to launch a “buy British” campaign in". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
